conclusion: Light changes speed and direction when passing from air to water, a phenomenon called refraction.
The angle of incidence is different from the angle of refraction.
Snell's Law relates the angles of incidence and refraction using refractive indices.
The refractive index of water is greater than that of air, causing light to bend towards the normal.
Point O is the intersection of line AB and the boundary; point O1 is where light enters the water.
As light enters water, it bends towards the normal, making the angle of refraction smaller than the angle of incidence.
The refracted ray AO1 will be closer to the normal than the incident ray.
Point O1, where light enters the water, will be to the right of point O.
Yes, point O1 is to the right of point O.
